conclusion: A metal rod slides on a smooth rail in a magnetic field, inducing an emf in the circuit.
The speed of the rod affects the induced current and the power of the external force.
The induced emf in the rod is given by \(\mathcal{E} = B \cdot L \cdot v\).
The current in the circuit is determined by Ohm's Law: \(I = \frac{B \cdot L \cdot v}{R}\).
The power delivered by the external force is \(P = B \cdot \frac{B \cdot L \cdot v}{R} \cdot L \cdot v = \frac{B^2 \cdot L^2 \cdot v^2}{R}\).
The ratio of the loop currents is \(1:2\) and the ratio of the powers of the external forces is \(1:4\).
